title: CosmosDB: Permission implementation
body:
## Implemented features

* All the Permission REST APIs methods have been implemented.
* A new specific client has been created: `PermissionClient`.
* Modified the authentication code to accept seamlessly either the *master* tokens (the one you get from the Azure Portal) and the *user permission* tokens (the one you get by explicitly granting access to a resource).  Please refer to the examples as usual for how to create and use user permission tokens.

## Breaking changes

* Removed enum `azure_sdk_cosmos::TokenType`
* Refactored struct `azure_sdk_cosmos::AuthorizationToken` into an enum to properly handle the permission based token. It also *loses* the account information (which goes into the `azure_sdk_cosmos::Client` struct instead). In practice you should replace in your code:

```rust
let authorization_token = AuthorizationToken::new(account, TokenType::Master, &master_key)?;	
let client = ClientBuilder::new(authorization_token)?;
```
with:

```rust
let authorization_token = AuthorizationToken::new_master(&master_key)?;
let client = ClientBuilder::new(account, authorization_token)?;
```

The other variant can be constructed from a `azure_sdk_cosmos::PermissionToken` struct (regardless on how obtained). For example: 

```rust
    let new_authorization_token: AuthorizationToken = create_permission_response
        .permission
        .permission_token
        .into();
```

## Issues closed

* #207 
* #208 
* #209 
* #210 
* #211

title: CosmosDB: Implemented User methods
body:
# CosmosDB - User methods

## Implemented as per REST API specification

* Create User
* List Users
* Delete User
* Replace User
* Get User

## New structs

* Added `UserClient` specific client.
* `User` struct (exact copy of [https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/cosmos-db/users](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/cosmos-db/users)).

Closes #202, #203, #204, #205, #206.

title: Issue/212/dev
body: Fixes #212.

title: Complete CosmosDB crate rewrite
body:
# A complete rewrite of CosmosDB crate 

## Main goals

1. Support for builder pattern everywhere.
2. Support for bleeding edge Azure CosmosDB REST APIs (version `2018-12-31`). This deprecates non-partitioned collections. The crate reflects that (see [https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/migrate-containers-partitioned-to-nonpartitioned](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/migrate-containers-partitioned-to-nonpartitioned)).
2. Compliance with the other Azure SDK crates.
3. Better use of recent Rust features.
4. More streamlined code. Each REST method has: `Request` and `Response`. The `Client` will create a type safe `Request` that has an `execute` function, callable only when all the mandatory fields have been filled. Some functions also export a `stream` function that takes care of the `ContinuationToken` for you.
5. Less fragmented code. Now it should be easier to find the relevant struct/trait in the repo.
6. Better encapsulation (there is still work to do here, many items can go from `pub` to `pub(crate)`).
7. Removed all `Ext` traits (those were really ugly :man_facepalming:).
8. Ability to create a `DatabaseClient` and a `CollectionClient` that embed the database name and collection name. These structs are light but help you avoid repeating the names over and over (most code uses a single collection anyway).
9. Make implementing the missing APIs easier.

## Issues closed

1. #181: Make CosmosDB API more similar to the rest of the crates.
2. #153: Cosmos DB: fix replace_collection().

## Drawbacks

1. No backward compatibility.
2. Many functions are more verbose (but *waaay* easier to understand and safer to use).

## Limitations

1. The functions always return `AzureError` in case of error. While `AzureError` is ergonomic to use it does not capture the nuances of every error. A more thoughtful approach is warranted.

title: Some api changes to make tablestorage api easier to use
body:
Some minor api mods as of https://github.com/MindFlavor/AzureSDKForRust/issues/174:
- if item is not found during get, it returns an Ok(None). Missing item is not an error
- insert and update moves the tableentry and return a new one with updated etag
- tablestrage creation api mods: create and create_if_not_exists

To be considered: Timestamp should be added to the TableEntry but I have a few questions:
- Should it be an Option that is filled on return and ignored in inputs (insert,delete,update) as timestamp cannot be altered ?
- What is the correct type to store the TimeStamp in rust ?

partially fixes: #214 

This is not a complete PR just a work in progress.

After your great PR of the tableentity i've tried to put together all the pieces of my project and it turned out for actix_rt (and actix_web) I need to bump the versions for some packages.
Unfortunately some of them had larger breaking change (ex http using self instead of &mut self in builders)

Some packages are still using the git version thus no crate publish is possible at the moment.

title: Working implementation of sas builder
body:
Hello,  I just wanted to propose this as an incomplete implementation of the Azure shared authorization signature protocol.  This code only supports the latest version of the protocol, and only generates signed urls for blobs.  I use this code currently in a work project, and suppose that it should be relatively easy to expand to support files and tables if the idea is acceptable to you.

An example usage is included in the PR.

title: Add stream_query_entities
body:
I need to be able to stream the table query results #143. This is an attempt to add the function and support. I think I'm down to some lifetime errors and parsing the headers. 

3 lifetime errors look like this:
```
Camerons-MacBook-Pro:AzureSDKForRust cameron$ cargo build
   Compiling azure_sdk_storage_table v0.20.3 (/Users/cameron/rs/AzureSDKForRust/azure_sdk_storage_table)
error: cannot infer an appropriate lifetime
   --> azure_sdk_storage_table/src/table/mod.rs:139:50
    |
137 |       ) ->  impl Stream<Item = T, Error = AzureError> {
    |             ----------------------------------------- this return type evaluates to the `'static` lifetime...
138 | 
139 |           stream::unfold(ContinuationState::Start, move |cont_state| {
    |  __________________________________________________^
140 | |             let cont = match cont_state {
141 | |                 ContinuationState::Start => None,
142 | |                 ContinuationState::Next(Some(cont)) => Some(cont),
...   |
156 | |             }))
157 | |         })
    | |_________^ ...but this borrow...
    |
note: ...can't outlive the anonymous lifetime #2 defined on the method body at 133:5
   --> azure_sdk_storage_table/src/table/mod.rs:133:5
    |
133 | /     pub fn stream_query_entities<T: DeserializeOwned>(
134 | |         &self,
135 | |         table_name: &str,
136 | |         query: Option<&str>,
...   |
158 | |         .flatten()
159 | |     }
    | |_____^
help: you can add a constraint to the return type to make it last less than `'static` and match the anonymous lifetime #2 defined on the method body at 133:5
    |
137 |     ) ->  impl Stream<Item = T, Error = AzureError> + '_ {
    |           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```

title: add count_blobs example
body:
I wrote this example to see how to page through the results with the next marker. It pages through the results and returns the total count of blobs.

To test it, I ran a [create_blobs.rs](https://gist.github.com/ctaggart/8b86ce938943443ebd85f4a7aa74ca4f) to populate a container with something more than 5000 results so that it would be forced to page.

title: Added support for Azure storage emulator
body:
This is another proposed solution for the Azure emulator support. It's pretty much the same code by [arnodb](https://github.com/arnodb)'s PR (available here [https://github.com/MindFlavor/AzureSDKForRust/pull/105](https://github.com/MindFlavor/AzureSDKForRust/pull/105)) so all the credit goes to him.

It does not break compatibility and it is behind a compile-time feature (so you don't pay the price of it outside development). Enable it with ```cargo run --features=emulator```.

I've also taken the time to remove one unnecessary String allocation.

title: v1 Storage support for blobs
body:
This pr modifies the `AccessTier` field of a blob to be Optional because v1 does not return it in the list_blobs XML unless it' explicitly set first.
v2 returned the field regardless along with the `AccessTierInferred` field (also optional). 

This should address [https://github.com/MindFlavor/AzureSDKForRust/issues/78](https://github.com/MindFlavor/AzureSDKForRust/issues/78) but I haven't checked it thoroughly. Since I will keep working on v2 please open issues in case of problems.

title: builder pattern for container (uncompleted)
body:
Builder pattern for `storage::Container`.

Each method is backed by a builder (moving builder) that is very verbose but very simple in essence. Optional fields are are pretty much simple (field() as getter with_field() as setter). Mandatory ones are more complicated because they change the `phantom` types attached to the struct. So whenever you set a mandatory field you do not get back *the same* type but a slightly different one instead. In order to call the `finalize` method - which creates the runnable future - you have to have **every** mandatory field set first. So, for example, the `CreateBuilder` defined like this:

```rust
pub struct CreateBuilder<'a, ContainerNameSet, PublicAccessSet> {
    p_container_name: PhantomData<ContainerNameSet>,
    p_public_access: PhantomData<PublicAccessSet>,
    client: &'a Client,
    container_name: Option<&'a str>,
    public_access: PublicAccess,
    timeout: Option<u64>,
    client_request_id: Option<&'a str>,
    metadata: HashMap<&'a str, &'a str>,
}
```

The phantom types statically required to be set in order to call `finalize()`. This is achieved by implementing finalize only for this type:

```rust
impl<'a> CreateBuilder<'a, Yes, Yes> {
    pub fn finalize(self) -> impl Future<Item = (), Error = AzureError> {
```

Of course each setter changes the type, for example setting the `container_name` field yields: 

```rust
    pub fn with_container_name(self, t: &'a str) -> CreateBuilder<'a, Yes, PublicAccessSet> {
 ```
The `Yes` type carries over even on optional fields.

So, in short, you must specify all mandatory fields or your code won't compile and you can specify as many optional fields as needed (in any order) before calling `finalize()`.

Also, this PR changes the calling convention. Now you use the `Client` instance to call the methods. The relevant methods are pulled in importing the correct trait. Please see the examples for this.

title: pub mod reshuffling and extras...
body:
- removed azure module from all paths
- partial flattening of a few sub modules under cosmos (to be continued)
- support for replace and delete document

* Removed unnecessary lifetime in ```impl Future``` return in storage. Fixes issue [https://github.com/MindFlavor/AzureSDKForRust/issues/33](https://github.com/MindFlavor/AzureSDKForRust/issues/33) by [ajsyp](https://github.com/ajsyp).
* Removed unused lifetimes.
* Replaced ```try!``` with ```?``` .
* Removes unused tokio dependency. PR [https://github.com/MindFlavor/AzureSDKForRust/pull/35](https://github.com/MindFlavor/AzureSDKForRust/pull/35) by [nayato](https://github.com/nayato).
* Removed ```Cargo.lock``` by [nayato](https://github.com/nayato).
* Update dependencies to state of the art (except ```future 0.2.x``` because ```Hyper`` does not support it yet).
* Fixed ```env_logger::init()``` because it no longer returns a ```Result```.
* RustFmt'd with latest ```rustfmt-preview``` from ```rustup```.

title: Removes Deref and AsRef impls for Database and Collection
body:
Per API guidelines Deref should not be implemented on Database or Collection: https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/api-guidelines/predictability.html#only-smart-pointers-implement-deref-and-derefmut-c-deref

Also I think AsRef<str> is misleading here as a whole struct with a number of fields is reduced to str for id. It isn't too bad to access id IMO like `db.id()` going forward.
